abstract.text: A future e + e − collider, such as the ILC or CLIC, would allow the Higgs sector to be probed with a precision significantly beyond that achievable at the High-Luminosity LHC.
A central part of the Higgs programme at an e + e − collider is the model-independent determination of the absolute Higgs couplings to fermions and to gauge bosons.
Here the measurement of the e + e − → HZ Higgsstrahlung cross section, using the recoil mass technique, sets the absolute scale for all Higgs coupling measurements.
Previous studies have considered σ(e + e − → HZ) with Z → + − , where = e, μ.
In this paper it is shown for the first time that a near model-independent recoil mass technique can be extended to the hadronic decays of the Z boson.
Because the branching ratio for Z → qq is approximately ten times greater than for Z → + − , this method is statistically more powerful than using the leptonic decays.
For an integrated luminosity of 500 fb −1 at a centre-of-mass energy of √ s = 350 GeV at CLIC, σ(e + e − → HZ) can be measured to ±1.8 % using the hadronic recoil mass technique.
A similar precision is found for the ILC operating at √ s = 350 GeV.
The centre-of-mass dependence of this measurement technique is discussed, arguing for the initial operation of a future linear collider at just above the top-pair production threshold.

body_text.text: Introduction

A future e + e − collider, such as the Compact Linear Collider (CLIC) [1] or the International Linear Collider (ILC) [2], would be complementary to the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) and the High-Luminosity LHC (HL-LHC), providing tests of beyond the Standard Model (SM) physics scenarios through a broad programme of highly precise measurements.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: A central part of the linear collider physics programme is a e-mail: thomson@hep.phy.cam.ac.uk the precise study of the properties of the Higgs boson.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The LHC and HL-LHC will provide an impressive range of Higgs physics measurements, establishing the general properties of the Higgs boson, such as its mass and spin.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The LHC will also provide measurements of the product of the Higgs production rate and Higgs decay branching fractions into different final states.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Current estimates suggest that ratios of couplings can be measured to 2-7 % (depending on the final state) with 3000 fb −1 of data [3].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: A number of recent studies, see for example [3,4], have indicated that modifications of the Higgs couplings due to beyond the SM (BSM) physics are almost always less than 10 % and can be as small as 1-2 % in a number of models.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: An e + e − collider would be a unique facility for precision Higgs physics [5][6][7], providing measurements of the Higgs boson branching ratios that may be an order of magnitude more precise than those achievable at the HL-LHC.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Such measurements may be necessary to reveal BSM effects in the Higgs sector.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Moreover, an e + e − collider provides the opportunity to make a number of unique measurements including:
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: (i) absolute measurements of Higgs couplings, rather than ratios;
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: (ii) a precise measurement of possible decays to invisible (long-lived neutral) final states; and
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: (iii) a <2 % [7] measurement of the total Higgs decay width, Γ H .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In addition, an e + e − collider operating at 1 TeV or above, for example CLIC or an upgraded ILC, would have sensitivity to the Yukawa coupling of the top quark to the Higgs boson and the Higgs self-coupling parameter λ, thus providing a direct probe of the Higgs potential.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This paper presents the first detailed study of the potential of making a model-independent measurement of g HZZ from the recoil mass distribution in e + e − → HZ with Z → qq, denoted as HZ(Z → qq).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The studies were initially performed in the context of the CLIC accelerator operating at √ s = 350 GeV.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The studies were repeated for the ILC operating at the same energy and for CLIC at √ s = 250 GeV and √ s = 420 GeV.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 1.1 Higgs production in e + e − collisions In e + e − collisions at √ s = 250−500 GeV, the two main Higgs production mechanisms are the Higgsstrahlung process, e + e − → HZ, and the WW-fusion process, e + e − → Hn ene , shown in Fig. 1.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: For m H ∼ 125 GeV, the cross section for the s-channel Higgsstrahlung process is maximal close to √ s = 250 GeV, whereas the cross section for the t-channel WW-fusion process increases with centre-of-mass energy, as indicated in Table 1.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The total HZ cross section is proportional to the square of the coupling between the Higgs and Z bosons, g HZZ , σ(e + e − → HZ) ∝ g 2 HZZ , and the cross sections for the exclusive final-state decays H → XX can be expressed as Once g HZZ has been determined in a model-independent manner, the ratio of the Higgsstrahlung and WW-fusion cross sections for the same exclusive Higgs boson final state (e.g. H → bb) yields g HWW .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Subsequently, the measurement of σ(e + e − → Hn ene ) × BR(H → WW * ) and/or Feynman diagrams for: (left) the Higgsstrahlung process e + e − → HZ, which dominates at √ s = 250 GeV; and (right) the WWfusion process e + e − → n ene H, which dominates at √ s > 500 GeV Table 1 The leading-order Higgs cross sections for the Higgsstrahlung and WW-fusion processes for m H = 125 GeV at three centre-of-mass energies.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The cross sections are calculated [9] including initial-state radiation and are shown for unpolarised electron/positron beams and assuming the baseline ILC polarisation of P(e − , e + ) = (−0.8, + 0.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: σ(e + e − → HZ) × BR(H → WW * ), which depend on g 4 HWW /Γ H and g 2 HWW g 2 HZZ /Γ H respectively, provide a determination of Γ H .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: At this point all measurements of exclusive Higgs decays provide absolute and model-independent determinations of the relevant coupling(s).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In practice, all measurements will be used as the input to a global fit.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Nevertheless, the determination of g HZZ from the recoil mass distribution in e + e − → HZ lies at the heart of this scientific programme.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: It has been pointed out [8] that off-shell effects in H → VV * with V = W, Z can break the model independence of the Higgs cross section and branching ratio measurements.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: However, for the centre-of-mass energies considered in this paper, off-shell effects, which depend strongly on √ s, are found to be small compared to the expected statistical uncertainties from the recoil mass measurements.

body_text.text: The leptonic recoil mass measurement
The Higgsstrahlung process provides the opportunity to study the couplings of the Higgs boson in a modelindependent manner.
body_text.section: The leptonic recoil mass measurement

body_text.text: This is unique to an electron-positron collider, where the clean experimental environment and the relatively low SM cross sections for background processes allow e + e − → HZ events to be selected based solely on the measurement of the four-momentum of the Z boson, regardless of how the Higgs boson decays.
body_text.section: The leptonic recoil mass measurement

body_text.text: The clearest topologies occur for Z → e + e − and Z → μ + μ − decays, which can be identified by first requiring that the measured dilepton invariant mass m is consistent with m Z .
body_text.section: The leptonic recoil mass measurement

body_text.text: The fourmomentum of the system recoiling against the Z boson is obtained from E rec = √ s − E and p rec = −p .
body_text.section: The leptonic recoil mass measurement

body_text.text: In e + e − → HZ events, the invariant mass of this recoiling system, m rec , will peak at m H .
body_text.section: The leptonic recoil mass measurement

body_text.text: Figure 2 shows the simulated recoil mass distribution in the ILD [10] detector concept for 250 fb −1 of ILC data at √ s = 250 GeV with beam polarisation P(e − , e + ) = (−0.8, + 0.3).
body_text.section: The leptonic recoil mass measurement

body_text.text: By combining both Z → μ + μ − and Z → e + e − decays, σ(HZ) can be measured to 2.6 %, leading to a determination of g HZZ with a precision of 1.3 % [5,10,11].
body_text.section: The leptonic recoil mass measurement

body_text.text: This result assumes 250 fb −1 of ILC data at √ s = 250 GeV with beam polarisation P(e − , e + ) = (−0.8, + 0.3).

body_text.text: Monte Carlo samples, detector simulation and event reconstruction

The CLIC results presented in this paper are based on detailed Monte Carlo (MC) simulation using: a full set of SM background processes; a detailed Geant4 [14,15] simulation of the CLIC_ILD detector concept [16]; and a full reconstruction of the simulated events.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo samples, detector simulation and event reconstruction

body_text.text: Monte Carlo event generation
The simulated SM event samples were generated using the WHIZARD 1.95 [9] program.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo event generation

body_text.text: The expected energy spectra for the CLIC beams, including the effects from beamstrahlung and the intrinsic machine energy spread, were used for the initial-state electrons and positrons.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo event generation

body_text.text: The process of fragmentation and hadronisation of final-state quarks and gluons was simulated using PYTHIA 6.4 [17] with a parameter set [18] that was tuned to OPAL e + e − data recorded at LEP.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo event generation

body_text.text: The decays of τ leptons were simulated using the TAUOLA package [19].
body_text.section: Monte Carlo event generation

body_text.text: The mass of the Higgs boson was taken to be m H = 126 GeV and the decays of the Higgs boson were simulated using PYTHIA with the branching fractions of [20].
body_text.section: Monte Carlo event generation

body_text.text: A dedicated sample of e + e − → HZ events with Higgs decays to "invisible" long-lived neutral particles was produced by artificially setting the Higgs boson lifetime to infinity.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo event generation

body_text.text: Because of the 0.5 ns bunch spacing in the CLIC beams, the pile-up of beam-induced backgrounds from the γγ → hadrons process was included in the simulated event samples to ensure its effect on the event reconstruction was accounted for.
body_text.section: Monte Carlo event generation

body_text.text: CLIC detector simulation and event reconstruction
The Geant4-based Mokka [21] program was used to simulate the detector response of the CLIC_ILD detector concept [16].
body_text.section: CLIC detector simulation and event reconstruction

body_text.text: The QGSP_BERT physics list was used to model the hadronic interactions of particles in the detectors.
body_text.section: CLIC detector simulation and event reconstruction

body_text.text: The hit digitisation and the event reconstruction were performed using the Marlin [22] software packages.
body_text.section: CLIC detector simulation and event reconstruction

body_text.text: Particle flow reconstruction was performed using PandoraPFA [12,23].
body_text.section: CLIC detector simulation and event reconstruction

body_text.text: An algorithm, using the individual reconstructed particles, was used to identify and remove approximately 90 % of the out-of-time background due to pile-up from γγ → hadrons; here the Loose particle flow object selection [16] was used.
body_text.section: CLIC detector simulation and event reconstruction

body_text.text: Jet finding was performed using the FastJet [24] package.
body_text.section: CLIC detector simulation and event reconstruction

body_text.text: Because of the presence of pile-up from γγ → hadrons, the ee_kt (Durham) algorithm employed at LEP is not effective as it clusters particles from pile-up into the reconstructed jets.
body_text.section: CLIC detector simulation and event reconstruction

body_text.text: Instead, the hadron-collider inspired k t algorithm, with the distance parameter R based on Δη and Δφ, was used with R = π/2.
body_text.section: CLIC detector simulation and event reconstruction

body_text.text: This algorithm allows particles to be clustered into "beam jets", aligned with the beam axis, in addition to jets seeded by high-momentum particles.
body_text.section: CLIC detector simulation and event reconstruction

body_text.text: Background from the pile-up of γγ → hadrons can, to a large degree, be removed by ignoring particles in the "beam jets", largely mitigating the impact of the beam background.
body_text.section: CLIC detector simulation and event reconstruction

body_text.text: The hadronic recoil mass study, presented in this paper, covers a wide range of HZ(Z → qq) final-state topologies ranging from two jets where Higgs decays to long-lived neutral particles, e + e − → HZ → (invis.)(qq), to six-jet toplogies from, for example, e + e − → HZ → (WW * → qqqq)(qq).
body_text.section: CLIC detector simulation and event reconstruction

body_text.text: For this reason, each reconstructed event is clustered into two-, three-, four-, five-and six-jet topologies, with "y-cut" variables used to indicate the underlying physical topology.
body_text.section: CLIC detector simulation and event reconstruction

body_text.text: For example, if an event is forced into a three-jet topology, y 34 is the k t value at which the event would be reconstructed as four jets and y 23 is the k t value at which the event would be reconstructed as two jets.
body_text.section: CLIC detector simulation and event reconstruction

body_text.text: ILC detector simulation and event reconstruction
The event generation and reconstruction for the ILC studies, presented in Sect.
body_text.section: ILC detector simulation and event reconstruction

body_text.text: 4, follows closely that described above.
body_text.section: ILC detector simulation and event reconstruction

body_text.text: The main differences are:
body_text.section: ILC detector simulation and event reconstruction

body_text.text: (i) the ILC beam spectrum, where the effects of beamstrahlung are less pronounced;
body_text.section: ILC detector simulation and event reconstruction

body_text.text: (ii) the detector simulation used the ILD detector concept for the ILC, rather than the CLIC_ILD model adapted for CLIC; and
body_text.section: ILC detector simulation and event reconstruction

body_text.text: (iii) the much longer ILC bunch spacing means that only intime background from γγ → hadrons needs to be included.
body_text.section: ILC detector simulation and event reconstruction

body_text.text: Hadronic recoil mass measurement at CLIC
In the process e + e − → HZ it is possible to cleanly identify Z → e + e − and Z → μ + μ − decays regardless of the H decay mode.
body_text.section: Hadronic recoil mass measurement at CLIC

body_text.text: Consequently, the selection efficiency is almost independent of the nature of the H decay.
body_text.section: Hadronic recoil mass measurement at CLIC

body_text.text: For Z → qq decays, the selection efficiency will depend more strongly on the Higgs decay mode.
body_text.section: Hadronic recoil mass measurement at CLIC

body_text.text: For example, in (H → bb)(Z → qq) events, the reconstruction of the Z boson is complicated by misassociations of particles to jets and by the threefold ambiguity in associating four jets to the Z and H. These ambiguities will increase with the number of jets in the final state.
body_text.section: Hadronic recoil mass measurement at CLIC

body_text.text: For this reason, it is much more difficult to construct an event selection, based only on the reconstructed candidate Z → qq decay, with a selection efficiency that is independent of the Higgs decay mode.
body_text.section: Hadronic recoil mass measurement at CLIC

body_text.text: Nevertheless it is possible to minimise this dependence.
body_text.section: Hadronic recoil mass measurement at CLIC

body_text.text: The strategy adopted here is to:
body_text.section: Hadronic recoil mass measurement at CLIC

body_text.text: (i) separate all simulated events into candidates for Higgs decays to "invisible" long-lived neutral particles and decays to visible final states;
body_text.section: Hadronic recoil mass measurement at CLIC

body_text.text: (ii) identify the di-jet system that is the best candidate for the Z → qq decay;
body_text.section: Hadronic recoil mass measurement at CLIC

body_text.text: (iii) reject events consistent with a number of clear background topologies using the information from the whole event;
body_text.section: Hadronic recoil mass measurement at CLIC

body_text.text: (iv) identify HZ(Z → qq) events solely based on the properties from the candidate Z → qq decay, first for the candidate visible Higgs decays and then for the candidate invisible Higgs decays; and
body_text.section: Hadronic recoil mass measurement at CLIC

body_text.text: (v) combine the results into a single measurement of σ(HZ).
body_text.section: Hadronic recoil mass measurement at CLIC

body_text.text: Separation into candidate visible and invisible Higgs decay samples
Hadronic events are selected by forcing each event into a two-jet topology and requiring at least three charged particles in each jet.
body_text.section: Separation into candidate visible and invisible Higgs decay samples

body_text.text: The surviving events are then divided into candidates for either visible H decays or invisible H decays, in both cases produced in association with a Z → qq.
body_text.section: Separation into candidate visible and invisible Higgs decay samples

body_text.text: Events are categorised as potential invisible H decays on the basis of the y-cut values in the k t jet-finding algorithm.
body_text.section: Separation into candidate visible and invisible Higgs decay samples

body_text.text: For invisible H decays, only the Z → qq system is visible in the detector, typically resulting in a two-jet topology (with the possibility that QCD radiation can increase the number of reconstructed jets).
body_text.section: Separation into candidate visible and invisible Higgs decay samples

body_text.text: Consequently, invisible H decays will have small values of y 23 and y 34 , the variables respectively representing the k t value at which an event transitions from two to three jets and from three to four jets, as indicated in Fig. 3
body_text.section: Separation into candidate visible and invisible Higgs decay samples

body_text.text: Recoil mass reconstruction
For each candidate HZ(Z → qq) event, the recoil mass is calculated from m
body_text.section: Recoil mass reconstruction

body_text.text: where E qq and p qq are the summed energy and momentum of the di-jet system from the identified candidate Z → qq decay.
body_text.section: Recoil mass reconstruction

body_text.text: In the case of the candidate invisible Higgs decay sample, the two jets are assumed to be from Z → qq.
body_text.section: Recoil mass reconstruction

body_text.text: The resulting recoil mass distribution for candidate invisible Higgs decays, which is strongly peaked around m rec ∼ m H , is shown in Fig. 4a.
body_text.section: Recoil mass reconstruction

body_text.text: In the case of the candidate visible Higgs decay sample, the situation is more complicated as this sample encompasses many different HZ event topologies.
body_text.section: Recoil mass reconstruction

body_text.text: For example, H → bb decays will result in a four-quark HZ final state, usually yielding four jets, whereas, H → WW * → qq n and H → WW * → qqqq decays will respectively usually yield five-and six-jet final states.
body_text.section: Recoil mass reconstruction

body_text.text: In all cases gluon radiation in the parton shower can increase the reconstructed jet multiplicity relative to the treelevel expectation.
body_text.section: Recoil mass reconstruction

body_text.text: In order to achieve the desired (near) model independence of the analysis, it is necessary to have a similar quality of recoil mass reconstruction for all Higgs boson visible decay modes.
body_text.section: Recoil mass reconstruction

body_text.text: This hinges on the correct identification and reconstruction of the Z → qq di-jet system.
body_text.section: Recoil mass reconstruction

body_text.text: The first stage is to force events in the candidate visible Higgs decay sample into a four-jet topology.
body_text.section: Recoil mass reconstruction

body_text.text: From the three possible di-jet combinations, the di-jet system with invariant mass m qq closest to m Z is identified as the candidate Z → qq decay and its energy and momentum are used to calculate the recoil mass m rec .
body_text.section: Recoil mass reconstruction

body_text.text: In selecting the candidate Z decay, only jets containing more than three charged particles are considered.
body_text.section: Recoil mass reconstruction

body_text.text: To improve the reconstruction of higher-jet-multiplicity final states, such as H → WW * → qqqq, each event is also forced into five jets and the di-jet system with mass closest to m Z is again identified as the candidate Z → qq decay.
body_text.section: Recoil mass reconstruction

body_text.text: The five-jet topology is only used if − log 10 (y 45 ) > 3.5 and both m qq and m rec are respectively closer to m Z and m H than the corresponding values from the four-jet reconstruction.
body_text.section: Recoil mass reconstruction

body_text.text: Even in the genuine six-parton topology HZ → (WW * )qq → (qqqq)qq only 13 % of events are reconstructed as five jets, for the remainder, the four-jet reconstruction is preferred.
body_text.section: Recoil mass reconstruction

body_text.text: However, provided the jets from the Z → qq decay are correctly identified, there is no need to correctly reconstruct the recoiling system as only the properties of the Z → qq decay are used in the subsequent analysis.
body_text.section: Recoil mass reconstruction

body_text.text: For this reason, allowing the pos-sibility of reconstructing events as six jets was found not to improve the overall recoil mass reconstruction.
body_text.section: Recoil mass reconstruction

body_text.text: Figure 4b shows the resulting recoil mass distribution for simulated HZ events with H → bb, H → WW * → qqqq and H → t + t − .
body_text.section: Recoil mass reconstruction

body_text.text: Despite the very different final states, similar recoil mass distributions are obtained.
body_text.section: Recoil mass reconstruction

body_text.text: Preselection

After dividing all events into either candidates for visible or invisible Higgs decays and having identified the two jets forming the candidate Z → qq system, preselection cuts are applied to reduce backgrounds from larger cross section SM processes such as e + e − → qq and e + e − → qqqq.
body_text.section: Preselection

body_text.text: Cuts are based on the invariant mass of the Z → qq candidate, m qq , and corresponding recoil mass, m rec .
body_text.section: Preselection

body_text.text: In addition, the invariant mass of all the visible particles not originating from the candidate Z → qq decay, m qq , is calculated.
body_text.section: Preselection

body_text.text: It is important to note that m qq is only used to reject specific background topologies in the preselection and is not used in the main selection; in HZ events m qq will depend strongly on the Higgs decay mode.
body_text.section: Preselection

body_text.text: The preselection cuts (most of which are common to the visible and invisible Higgs selections) are:
body_text.section: Preselection

body_text.text: -the event must be broadly consistent with being HZ,  The effects of the preselection cuts are summarised in Table 2.
body_text.section: Preselection

body_text.text: The events passing the preselection cuts are put forward as candidate HZ(Z → qq) events with either:
body_text.section: Preselection

body_text.text: (i) visible H decay products; or
body_text.section: Preselection

body_text.text: (ii) invisible H decay products, depending on whether the event was consistent with a two-jet topology or not.
body_text.section: Preselection

body_text.text: The first two cuts listed above result in the largest loss of signal efficiency for the visible Higgs decay selection.
body_text.section: Preselection

body_text.text: The qq n background in the visible Higgs decay preselection could have been significantly reduced by rejecting events with visible high-energy isolated leptons, but this would have introduced a bias against H decays with leptons in the final state.
body_text.section: Preselection

body_text.text: Selection of HZ→qq with visible Higgs decays
After preselection, the main backgrounds in the visible Higgs decay analysis arise from e + e − → qq n and e + e − → qqqq, dominated by WW, single-W (Wen e ) and ZZ processes.
body_text.section: Selection of HZ→qq with visible Higgs decays

body_text.text: The event selection is based entirely on the reconstructed candidate Z → qq decay in the event.
body_text.section: Selection of HZ→qq with visible Higgs decays

body_text.text: The properties of the remainder of the event (or the event as a whole) are not used as their inclusion would break the desired model independence of the selection.
body_text.section: Selection of HZ→qq with visible Higgs decays

body_text.text: For example, the background from e + e − → qq n can be significantly reduced by placing a lower bound on the total visible energy in the event, however such a cut would bias the selection against Higgs decays with missing energy, such as H → t + t − .
body_text.section: Selection of HZ→qq with visible Higgs decays

body_text.text: The event selection uses a relative likelihood approach with discriminant variables based on the properties of can-didate Z → qq decay.
body_text.section: Selection of HZ→qq with visible Higgs decays

body_text.text: Two event categories are considered:
body_text.section: Selection of HZ→qq with visible Higgs decays

body_text.text: (a) the e + e − → HZ → Hqq signal; and
body_text.section: Selection of HZ→qq with visible Higgs decays

body_text.text: (b) all non-Higgs background processes.
body_text.section: Selection of HZ→qq with visible Higgs decays

body_text.text: The relative likelihood for an event being classified as signal is defined as
body_text.section: Selection of HZ→qq with visible Higgs decays

body_text.text: where the individual absolute likelihood L j for the event class j (signal or background) is formed from normalised probability distributions P j i (x i ) of the discriminant variables x i for that event class j:
body_text.section: Selection of HZ→qq with visible Higgs decays

body_text.text: where σ j presel is the cross section after preselection for event class j.
body_text.section: Selection of HZ→qq with visible Higgs decays

body_text.text: The discriminant variables used in the likelihood selection, all of which are based on the candidate Z → qq decay, are:

body_text.text: Such a measurement is competitive with that obtainable from the leptonic recoil mass measurement at √ s = 250 GeV, where a precision of ±2.6 % [5] is achievable with 250 fb −1 of data (assuming −80 % and +30 % polarisation of the electron and positron beams).

body_text.text: If it can be argued that the hadronic recoil mass measurement is effectively independent of the nature of the Higgs boson decay modes (including possible extensions to the SM), then the arguments for operating an e + e − linear collider at √ s ∼ 250 GeV are greatly reduced; almost all other measurements of the properties of the Higgs boson are found to benefit from higher centre-of-mass energies [5].

body_text.text: Summary and conclusions

This paper presents the first detailed study of the potential of the hadronic recoil mass analysis at a future linear collider, both for visible Higgs decay modes and possible BSM invisible decay modes.
body_text.section: Summary and conclusions

body_text.text: By combining the analyses for visible and invisible modes, it is shown that the measured e + e − → HZ(Z → qq) cross section does not depend strongly on the nature of the Higgs boson decay and thus provides a model-independent determination of g HZZ .
body_text.section: Summary and conclusions

body_text.text: The statistical precision achievable at CLIC operating at √ s = 350 GeV with 500 fb −1 of data with unpolarised beams is Δ σ HZ ≈ ±1.8 %.
body_text.section: Summary and conclusions

body_text.text: A similar precision is obtained for the ILC with 350 fb −1 and the nominal beam polarisation of P(e + , e − ) = (+30 %, −80 %).
body_text.section: Summary and conclusions

body_text.text: In both cases the branching ratio to invisible decay modes can be constrained to BR(H → invis.) < 1 % at 90 % confidence level.
body_text.section: Summary and conclusions

body_text.text: It is demonstrated that √ s = 350 GeV is likely to be close to the optimal energy for the hadronic recoil mass analysis; at lower centre-of-mass energies there is less discrimination between signal and background and at higher centre-of-mass energies the measurement is limited by the worsening recoil mass resolution.
body_text.section: Summary and conclusions

body_text.text: It is often stated that operation of a future e + e − linear collider close to threshold ( √ s ∼ 250 GeV) is necessary to provide an absolute measurement of the coupling between the Higgs boson and the Z boson, g HZZ .
body_text.section: Summary and conclusions

body_text.text: This is based on the determination of g HZZ from the recoil mass analysis for e + e − → HZ(Z → + − ).
body_text.section: Summary and conclusions

body_text.text: The results presented in this paper show that, for a comparable running time, a statistically more precise measurement can be obtained from e + e − → HZ(Z → qq) events at √ s = 350 GeV.
body_text.section: Summary and conclusions

body_text.text: This conclusion argues against initial operation of a future linear collider at significantly below the top-pair production threshold.
body_text.section: Summary and conclusions
